description.narrative: The overall project goal is to build sustainable peace in communities by deepening democratic participation of women and youth in local governance through promotion of accountability and transparency. The key outcomes are: 1) Enhanced and strengthened capacities of Women and youth to participate in governance and democratic issues as equal partners with men in demanding their rights, 2)Local and national policy frameworks on governance, democracy, peace-building and conflict resolution(Local government, central government, NPRC, ZHC) are inclusive of community inputs from 3 districts.The main problem being addressed by the project is as follows: Local authorities as duty bearers are not used to being held to account because of an entrenched culture of fear and intimidation and lack of adequate knowledge and capacity by rights holders to hold the duty bearers to account. There has been an express interest in national challenges of accountability without adequate emphasis by the rights holders to hold the local government to account on service delivery.Disregard of engagements between community members and local authorities and leaders in the governance processes has created gaps, mistrust, corruption and lack of information on community developmental issues creating tense relations between the two groups. State institutions have been politicized and co-opted into partisan agendas coupled with impunity. Rights holders for this project mainly include rural women who are being marginalised in decision making processes at local and national levels, mainly due to political violence and socialisation processes. This project mainly falls within the Democracy intervention area (strengthening democratic culture objective) in the current Diakonia Zimbabwe’s Strategic Plan and Programme for 2016-2020. It will be implemented by Heal Zimbabwe Trust (HZT) in Zaka, Gutu and Bikita rural districts in Masvingo province.
This project mainly contributes to results within Democratic culture. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
